dlgPart.npc_text:
The pass changed in your absence. The towers are gone, replaced by a crude catapult and wooden barricades in front of the stone walls. The barricades don’t block the approach, but create a narrow corridor. The men look less like brigands and more like soldiers.
“Drilled them every day,” says Bass as if reading your thoughts. “I told them that the Ordu will bugger them first and only then kill them, so they are sufficiently motivated to fight till the last breath. How was your trip?”

dlgAnsw.text: “I did the best I could. So, what’s the plan?”
“I convinced them to stay on the plains.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “The walls won’t hold them for long and the Ordu are better marksmen. If I put my men on the wall or the towers, they will be dead the moment they raise their heads. We can’t hold them all at the wall, but we can fight them here, a few at a time. That’s what the barricades are for – to narrow the way in. We light them up to keep them from climbing over them and use this baby,” he points at the catapult, “to keep them from rushing in all at once.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What are you going to throw at them? Boulders?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “That’s the plan,” says Bass proudly.

dlgAnsw.text: “Are you sure it’s going to work?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Would you believe me if I said yes?”

dlgAnsw.text: “What are you going to throw at them? Boulders?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Clay pots, filled with the black powder. I have enough for eight shots.”
"Not a lot. Two hours at most."

dlgAnsw.text: "Let me see what I can do to help."

dlgPart.npc_text: "They seem to be taking their sweet time getting here, so we have more than a few hours to kill."

dlgAnsw.text: "Let me see what I can do to help."

dlgPart.npc_text: "What can you do in such a short time?"

They are rushed by the nearby Guards, eager to take advantage of the opportunity, but the Ordu recover fast and push forward.

dlgPart.npc_text: FIGHT - Ordu 1

Another group manages to get through the fire and explosions. The ground behind them is slick with blood and covered with mangled bodies and torn limbs. Not a pretty sight. Hopefully, it looks very discouraging to the Ordu.
You see Thorgul among the attackers and salute him with your weapon. He doesn't return the gesture.

As if on cue, Belgutai's forces start withdrawing, leaving Thorgul's loyalists to their fate. You get ready to charge, when you notice that the fighting stopped.
You turn your head and see rows of the Imperial Guards standing still at the other entrance to the pass.
“Good show,” says their Commander.
FIGHT - Ordu 2

You see the Ordu getting ready to attack. The catapult is silent. “Gotta give them one thing – they are persistent,” says Bass appearing next to you. “I hoped they would have run by now. Come, <charname>, don’t tell me you wanted to live forever.”
Suddenly, the Ordu stop dead in their tracks. They stand there for a moment, then turn around and run. You turn your head and see rows of the Imperial Guards standing still at the other entrance to the pass.
“Good show,” says their Commander.

“Commander Carbo,” says Bass, saluting. “I wasn’t sure you were going to come.”
“And miss all this excitement?” laughs Carbo. “We are the Imperial Guards, Bass. We don’t leave our own. I’ve gotta give it to you, Bass. You held your end well. And this must be <charname>. Hell of a fight, <son/girl>. Get ready to travel. Dux Gaius Aetius Paullus wants to meet you.”
“Didn’t I say Dux? Commander-in-Chief, if you’re rusty on the ranks.”
"Too bad," says Bass. "The boys would really have liked a little exercise, since it's been a long time they've been waiting for this. Better luck next time, eh?"

dlgAnsw.text: “What can you tell me about Paullus?”

“That was fun,” says Bass. “We should do it again sometime.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What can you tell me about Paullus?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Paullus rules the Imperial Guards with an iron fist. He isn’t big on second opinions and such. He knows what’s best for the Guards and everyone else, so you either fall in line and stand behind him hundred and ten per cent, or you end up guarding a pass in the middle of fucking nowhere. If you’re lucky.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Is that why Carrinas ended up in Teron?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Then you are given a shitty squad of people nobody likes and sent patrolling the wasteland. It’s a death sentence. You either take it and die in some skirmish or refuse and get crucified for insubordination.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Is that why Carrinas ended up in Teron?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “They didn’t see eye to eye. Paullus hoped that Carrinas would come around, but he never did. They had a heated argument and the next day Carrinas was sent to Teron.”
“Carrinas was tired of waiting, tired of sitting around. He thought that Paullus was doing nothing but surrounding himself with sycophants and building his own little dominion.”

“If you ask me, one lord is as bad as the next one, and the Imperial Guards’ top brass is no exception. When I first got this post, I was depressed for a week. Then I thought about it and realized that I got the best post there is. It’s nice and quiet and far away from all that shit. It’s my own little paradise on earth, even if it doesn't look like much.”

“Carbo is Paullus’ lapdog. No man is more loyal to him and no man is better. He’s earned his stripes. Legionaries love him because despite his rank, he is one of them – he sleeps in the same tents, eats the same shit, and fights shoulder to shoulder with them. Some say that he’s a soldier at heart, but I suspect that he’s a killer at heart. He loves the thrill of a fight. Try to stay on his good side.”
“How the fuck did you do it?”
“No shit. Well, the boys will be disappointed. Some of them, anyway. Care for some wine?”

Your celebration is interrupted by the sound of marching men. You step outside and see rows of battle-ready legionaries. Their officer walks toward you and Bass.
“Commander Carbo!” says Bass without any enthusiasm, saluting him.

“We've got your teary-eyed letter, Bass,” says Carbo, dragging his words, “and come all the way here to fight some savages, who appear to be missing. What happened, Bass? They took one look at your concraption,” he points at the catapult, “and ran away in fear?”
“We were ready to fight,” reports Bass, “but <charname> here talked them out of it. Make peace, not war, <he/she> said and the Ordu agreed. Savages, Commander.”
“Are you some kind of peacenik, <charname>?” inquires Carbo. “Think we should love our enemies? My men and I marched for ten days straight. Is this some kind of joke to you, <boy/girl>?”

dlgAnsw.text: “No, Commander. I killed the khan and his men, and told the new khan to stay away from the pass.”

dlgAnsw.text: “I didn’t know that help was on the way. To save the lives of these men, I made a deal with the Ordu – they stay on the other side of the mountains in exchange for food and steel.”
“Isn’t bad peace better than good war?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“Well done then. You taught these bloody savages a little respect and showed them that one Imperial Guard is worth a hundred of them.” He looks at Bass and frowns. “If he’s a real Guard, of course.
“Get ready to travel. Dux Gaius Aetius Paullus wants to meet you.”
“You offered to feed and arm our enemies? That’s treason. I would have executed you on the spot, but lucky for you Dux Gaius Aetius Paullus wants to meet you.”

“A bad peace is worse than any war, especially a good war. A bad peace is a prelude to war as all it does is give your enemies time to grow stronger. It’s good only if you’re the weak one.
“Anyway, we’ll have plenty of time to fill in the gaps in your education. Get ready to travel. Dux Gaius Aetius Paullus wants to meet you.”
